Pour ma part je me satisfaisait de mon Vmax 1200 avec v-boost, 8l au cent 
en moyenne. Sinon 5L au cent pour un vingtaine de chevaux de gagner c'est 
pas donné.

comments.text: j'aime le 500 2t haaaaaaaaa

comments.text: oui mais feu le 2 temps
comments.author: TATARSTAN59500

top_comment.text:
Elle est horriblement moche la Diavel ... Ducati a perdu son savoir faire 
en terme de belle moto ...﻿
top_comment.author: blu3kill3er

comments.text: clair dugachi comme le joeur le v-max est bcp plus stylé ;)
comments.author: fullmajik

comments.text:
Y'a pas besoin d'avoir 40 ans pour jugé si on trouve ça beau ou pas! Moi 
j'aime bien la forme! Oui c'est épais.. Mais moi j'aime bien se côté 
massif.. Après chacun ses goûts..
comments.author: BlueMyro

comments.text:
Je n'ai pas écrit "elle est moche". Je laisse ça à Blu3kill3r....Je préfère 
dire "elle ne me plait pas". Et néanmoins, je peux ajouter qu'elle manque 
de style, c'est lourdaud et épais. Mais c'est effectivement une affaire de 
gout.Par ailleurs, on peut avoir 16 ans "seulement" et acquérir de bonnes 
notions en termes d'esthétique et savoir faire la part entre un coup de 
crayon audacieux et un pur mauvais gout  ;-)
comments.author: Lonewolf

comments.text:
Pour moi c'est comme tout... C'est pas moche! C'est pas a ton goût.. J'ai 
16 ans et moi j'aime beaucoup... J'trouve qu'elle a un look agressif, 
Moderne et classe a la fois...
comments.author: BlueMyro

comments.text:
on ne peut tout de même pas dire que Ducati a perdu son sens de 
l'esthétique. La Diavel a un look - nous dirons...- très particulier, mais 
d'autres Ducati sont magnifiques, par exemple les Panigale.
comments.author: Lonewolf

comments.text: C'est une histoire de goût, Moi je la trouve magnifique...
comments.author: BlueMyro

comments.text:
et que dire du tarif... Toutes ces meules à plus de 20.000 euros, ça 
commence à me sortir par les narines ! Il en faut pour tous les gouts, mais 
on peut se douter qu'une moto de ce tarif là n'est pas pour tout le monde, 
et qu'elle dispose d'atouts. Sinon à quoi bon !
comments.author: Lonewolf

comments.author: Moto Journal

captions.text: Once upon a time, a man was rummaging in his old motorcycle stuffs
Suddenly, he fell on a box he had never noticed before.
But what should have been a simple motorcycle trip
A ticket to travel back in time
will become much more surprising
The Milan Motorcycle show have got 100 years !
well, it's fortunate, i've got my new bike to run in !
With his Diavel, Ducati exceeds standards and doesn’t respect the categories.
The Diavel is a cross between a roadster, a custom bike
and even a dragster, as its V-twin owns more than 160 horsepowers !
As for the electronic driving helps, the Italian has an endowment worthy of a hypersport bike
three engine maps, traction control adjustable on 8 positions and ABS.
Sit down on the beast, and you won't remain anonymous any longer
An hyper-aggressive look, exhausts screaming to death, a LED headlight...
Hard to be more ostentatious !
Especially for this carbon version,
which as his name suggests has a full carbon fairing and forged aluminium wheels
And an expensive price :  € 21,590 !
But beware, the Diavel is not only an exhibition machine.
And its dynamic performances are quite impressive.
How a bike that long, wearing such a big rear tire and has a driving position « feet first »,
can be so efficient ?
Braking is powerful, the chassis is surprisingly agile.
As for the engine, the Testastretta combines flexibility at low speed and big power in top RPM
A real sensation factory.
Be careful, however, when we tickle the engine,
it becomes rather greedy with a consumption which easily exceeds 7 litres per 100 km
my bike ?!
and what is this moustache ??!!
Yes, you got it !
This magic ticket allows to travel back in time ...
Can you hear the sound of the 2 stroke ?
The sound of an angry bee, which softly whispers in your ear
be careful, it sounds like high side !
Released in 1984, the RDLC embodies the time of the mythical 500 GP bikes
The days when you could go to your dealer
and buy the same bike as Kenny Roberts, Christian Sarron or Freddy Spencer
More than a motorcycle, the Yamaha is a fantasy.
There are only few machines that plunge you, at this point, in the world of racing.
You ride with an eye pointed on the tachometer, trying to keep the engine above 6500 rpm,
the limit which the Japanese gets worked on.
Each rotation of the handle gives you chills.
Each braking gives you cold sweats.
Because the two discs clamped by callipers with opposed pistons don’t work very well.
Fortunately, the chassis is not vicious
In the corner entries, we feel like a tacking movement.
But little by little, you can tame this regular movement and then,
you begin to gain confidence, to put a harder rhythm. And you feel like a real pilot.
When we detail the Yamaha, we cannot miss the V-four
which had in the 80’s the reputation of being a real headache for mechanics.
Finally, we stay doubtful in front of the chubby lines of this old sportbike.
And her hospitality, once we are onboard
Comfortable seat, very good protection, neutral riding position
Today we would classify it definitely in the category of sport GT bikes.
Haaaaa, the Honda CB750 !
The one who make the bike enter the modern world.
ha, 1971 this time.Well, it's a good year...
In the late 60s, riding a motorcycle was still an adventure.
You'd better know some mechanics, be patient, and not very demanding in handling and braking
And then in 1969, the democratic revolution happened
The 750 Four, the big engine that all bikers were waiting for.
Powerful, reliable, easy to handle, affordable...
In short, the bike for all !
From the outset, we are seduced by the overall balance of the CB
By this incredible homogeneity, which was yet in this time the trademark of Honda
We fall in love with the flexibility and the docility of the big four-cylinder in line.
We ride, slowly but surely, around 5,000 rpm. No need to go higher.
For sure, modern BT 45 Bridgestone's and second brake disc help a lot
We easily spin around from one corner to the other
45 years later, many contemporary basic machines do not have much more to offer.
The fashion cycle makes the things well
and the look of the Honda Four is nowadays fashionable.
The big engine with air-cooled, the carburettors, the exhaust flutes,
the gold colour, the pure and simple lines...
Enough for a bearded hipster to succumb, right ?
On the road that leads us to Milan
this is undoubtedly our best ally, as the Honda seems to be tireless.
Well, hard to say the same for the driver, his stomach begins to cry.
Here, we touch the basic one.
The bike made in real iron, the bike for man.
Let's go !
Already, to start the engine, you have to tickle the carbs to bring some gasoline
and give a strong kick-start.
The Norton 88 was typically the motorcycle for rockers, for yobs
The one which, in 2 seconds, put you in the skin of the rebel of your street.
This bike, ancestor of the famous Commando, dates back to 1954.
. A time when English machines were the best in matter of performances.
When you’re onboard, the change is complete
Particularly because of the inverted right gear selector
And during the first wheel laps, I can tell you that you spend your time thinking of what you’re doing.
It's a bit like trying to drive and, in the same time, solve a very long division.
It vibrates, it backfires, it's primitive ...
And then, when it’s time to brake, it’s better to anticipate.
Must be said that the front and back are drums brake.
Then, about the engine, we find a 500cc twin cylinder in line powered by two big carbs.
There is also a separate gearbox, which was the norm at this time.
The last few kilometers before getting to Milan International Fair
are ridden with a certain amount of stress.
Especially once we got there, we still had to find the right entry...
Excuse-me, are we at the Milan International Motor Show ?
Yes, we are. But you're a little early. The fair opens from the 6th to the 9th of november.
I'm sorry, you have to come back later...

title: Essai motos mythiques : Ducati Diavel, Yamaha 500 RDLC, Honda CB750... (English Subtitles)
